comments.body: Tests are for Node context by default and there isn't a `initSqlJs()` function in the global scope. See the comment on line 3 for one way (well, not the only way) of resolving this.
This should be the final piece. After the change it's good to go.
Sorry, I don't quite understand. I already imported `initSqlJs` in line 3, as suggested by you.

It's only a comment. What I meant was:
1. If `initSqlJs` is not imported, here this identifier has the semantic of accessing a global object. It is injected to the global scope only when it is *not* loaded as a module (e.g. using `<script>`). So compilation passes, but it will throw a runtime error when you compile the test code and run in a Node environment (which is quite popular for tests).
2. If the symbol is correctly imported, for example, being fixed as suggested, then there's nothing to worry about. â† Now we are here
